content.question: During pre-flight, while checking the route entered in the FMS by the pilot, it is noticed that the FMS navigation databasee is out-of-date. The decision is taken to change the FMS navigation database cycle to the current cycle. After changing the navigation database cycle...

options.A: The FMS will restart, deleting all entered information.
options.B: There will be data missing on some of the sector legs.
options.C: The previously entered route data will remain unaffected.
options.D: All previously entered route data will be deleted.

key_points: The information stored in the FMC is called its data base
The data base is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation
The FMGC navigation data base includes most information that would normally be determined by referring to navigation charts
learning.explanation: The information stored in the FMC is called its data base. The data base is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation. The FMGC navigation data base includes most information that would normally be determined by referring to navigation charts. The stored information includes the location of navigation aids, airports, runways and other airline selected information such as SIDs, STARs, approaches and company routes. The FMGC contains two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each set corresponds to the normal revision cycle for navigation charts. During preflight the flight crew can select which set is active. Cycling the database erases the primary and secondary flight plans, as well as stored data. The flight crew must never do this in flight. The contents of the navigation data base are updated by maintenance every 28 days.

metadata.topic: Flight Management System (FMS)/Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS)

content.question: After the failure of MCDU 1, an aircraft equipped with dual FMS architecture will operate in (1) _____ mode. Using MCDU 2, the crew can program (2) _____.

options.A: (1) single; (2) FMS 1 only.
options.B: (1) independent; (2) FMS 2 only.
options.C: (1) single; (2) FMS 2 only.
options.D: (1) dual; (2) either FMS.

key_points: The FMS is responsible for computing and generating various flight management data, including flight plans, navigation, performance, and fuel calculations
The (M)CDU provides the interface for pilots to input and manage data related to the flight plan, performance, and other functions
Modern aircraft are designed to maximize redundancy and minimize inconvenience
learning.explanation: The FMS is responsible for computing and generating various flight management data, including flight plans, navigation, performance, and fuel calculations. The (M)CDU provides the interface for pilots to input and manage data related to the flight plan, performance, and other functions. Modern aircraft are designed to maximize redundancy and minimize inconvenience. In the event of a failure of one (M)CDU, the other (M)CDUs can be used to communicate with either or both FMSs in dual mode. Bottom line is: In the event of a single FMS failure, the second system can operate the aircraft successfully in single mode, which will also activate automatically if the cross-talk bus connecting the FMSs in dual mode fails. However, if only a (M)CDU fails, the system can still remain in dual mode, but monitoring the system and making changes to the flight path would only be possible through the functional (M)CDU.

key_points: The Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS) performs navigation functions and lateral and vertical flight planning functions
It also computes performance parameters and guides the aircraft along a preplanned route

The Flight Management (FM) part controls the following functions: - Navigation - Management of flight planning - Prediction and optimisation of performance - Management of navigation radios - Management of displays The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from a IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position
learning.explanation: The Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS) performs navigation functions and lateral and vertical flight planning functions. It also computes performance parameters and guides the aircraft along a preplanned route. The Flight Management (FM) part controls the following functions: - Navigation - Management of flight planning - Prediction and optimisation of performance - Management of navigation radios - Management of displays The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from a IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position. The flight crew may check the position computation using the POSITION MONITOR page.

content.question: On a typical Navigation Display (ND) the current in-flight Wind Velocity (W/V) is displayed. Where is the W/V information derived from?

options.A: It is uploaded by data link from the latest available meteorological forecasts.
options.B: It is determined by the FMC from inputs of heading, drift, True Airspeed (TAS) and ground speed.
options.C: It is manually entered by the pilots, based on the latest information available.
options.D: It is entered into the FMC by either the pilots or dispatch/operations.

key_points: Navigation Display (ND) shows ‘instant’ wind velocity based upon on board computations are now quite accurate when instant variation is not required
Updating of on-board readouts of wind velocity depends on the system which generates them
FMS wind is the most accurate, because it is based upon changes of GPS or DME/DME position, but it may only be re-calculated every 30 seconds
learning.explanation: Navigation Display (ND) shows ‘instant’ wind velocity based upon on board computations are now quite accurate when instant variation is not required. Updating of on-board readouts of wind velocity depends on the system which generates them. FMS wind is the most accurate, because it is based upon changes of GPS or DME/DME position, but it may only be re-calculated every 30 seconds. The FMC (Flight Management Computer) is the box that calculates the wind. The inputs are: Track, heading and groundspeed from the nav system (varies between models, but typically inertial with updates from GPS and terrestrial navaids); and TAS from the ADC (Air Data Computer) The FMS solves for the final side of the vector triangle and computes wind (side 1- HDG/TAS; side 2- TRK/GS; side 3- Wind direction/magnitude). In a perfect world, the difference between TRK/GS and HDG/TAS is actual wind (direction, magnitude).

metadata.topic: Flight Management System (FMS)/Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS)

content.question: The data base of a FMC (Flight Management Computer) is divided into two major sections…

options.A: aeroplane performance and fuel saving.
options.B: aeroplane performance and navigation.
options.C: navigation and meteorology.
options.D: inertial and navigation.

key_points: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary components for the FMC to be operative
The performance database includes aircraft drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path
The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow
learning.explanation: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary components for the FMC to be operative. The performance database includes aircraft drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path. The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow. The navigation database of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav database is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports Navaids Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.

content.question: At the beginning of the flight, when initialising the FMS, you have the option to choose between the current and the upcoming version of the navigation database. You confirm the upcoming version of the database, by accident and without noticing. This decision…

options.A: Will lead to a blockage of the FMS computer. The screen will be frozen and the computer has to be reset by the pilot.
options.B: Could lead to an unsafe situation by including waypoints, SID and STAR data that are only available at a later date.
options.C: Will be announced by the FMS as WRONG DATABASE VERSION so that the pilot can correct the situation.
options.D: Has no further implications. In the background logic the FMS will use the current database.

key_points: The use of a new, not-yet valid database could be a threat to flight safety
In the best case, it could produce a flight discontinuity if a waypoint or airway has changed, and the FMS is not able to guide the aircraft along the entered route
However, it is possible that the FMS continues to follow a flight plan, but the aircraft will take a path that is unexpected to the pilots and ATC
learning.explanation: The use of a new, not-yet valid database could be a threat to flight safety. In the best case, it could produce a flight discontinuity if a waypoint or airway has changed, and the FMS is not able to guide the aircraft along the entered route. However, it is possible that the FMS continues to follow a flight plan, but the aircraft will take a path that is unexpected to the pilots and ATC. Remember that if there are changes to routes, SIDS, STARS or waypoints, the changes are only effective after midnight UTC on the nominated date.

metadata.topic: Flight Management System (FMS)/Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS)

content.question: While preparing the cockpit, the pilot initiated the route loading process into the Flight Management System (FMS). Due to a distraction, the pilot inadvertently replaced the current navigation database with a newer version before its designated activation date. Is this problematic, and if so, why?

options.A: It can be an issue because certain waypoints and airways might have changed their coordinates, and the aircraft will follow an incorrect routing.
options.B: It is not a problem if the captain’s FMS still has the old (correct) database.
options.C: It is an issue because the pilot will need to load the flight plan again.
options.D: It is a problem, and you will probably get a warning.

key_points: Learning Objectives 022
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 022.11.02.01.05: Explain the threats and implications to the pilot of changing the database by error either on the ground or while flying. The Flight Management Computer (FMC) holds two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days to align with the standard revision cycle for navigation charts. Prior to flight, the flight crew can designate the active set, which the FMC employs for navigation computations. The maintenance department updates the contents of these navigation databases every 28 days. By the time the navigation chart revision date arrives, the new data is already integrated into the FMC and available for selection. Should pilots mistakenly switch navigation databases while on the ground or in-flight, it could compromise elements of the planned flight route, potentially leading to hazardous deviations in performance and navigation. In the best case, such an error may result in a flight plan discontinuity - this is typically flagged by multiple FMS warnings. However, there's also the possibility that the FMS can still adhere to the flight plan, albeit leading the aircraft along an unexpected path, causing both pilots and Air Traffic Control (ATC) personnel to lose situational awareness. This scenario could potentially result in perilous close encounters between aircraft.

content.question: From the options below, which is the most complete regarding navigation receivers for FMC position updates?

options.A: GPS, INS, DME, ILS
options.B: GPS, INS, VOR/DME, LOC
options.C: GPS, INS, DME, NDB
options.D: GPS, INS, DME, NDB, ILS

key_points: LO 022
learning.explanation: LO 022.11.03.01.07 - Explain typical position inputs to an FMS: GPS; IRS; DME; VOR; LOC; runway threshold (RWY THR). The FMC calculates the present position of the aircraft from GPS, IRS/INS, DME, VOR, LOC, and other navigation system inputs such as co-ordinates of the runway threshold position. Additionally, the FMS contains dedicated radio-navigation receivers that are automatically tuned in by the system for redundancy, efficiency, and simplicity purposes. The FMC uses its calculated present position to generate lateral steering commands along the active leg to the active waypoint. To function, the FMC requires position information from at least one IRS/INS.

content.question:
In order to calculate the optimum vertical profile, the FMS uses the performance database. Before the flight, during the FMS preparation, the performance database has to be checked for:
1. Correct engines types and configuration
2. Correct aircraft type and variant
3. Current navigational data cycle

options.A: 1 and 3 are correct.
options.B: 1, 2 and 3 are correct.
options.C: 2 and 3 are correct.
options.D: 1 and 2 are correct.

key_points: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database
The Performance Database contains an average model of the aeroplane and its engines
This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database. The Performance Database contains an average model of the aeroplane and its engines. This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands. Additionally, the relevant data can be displayed and this reduces the need for the flight crew to refer to a performance manual during flight. The data stored includes: - aeroplane drag characteristics aeroplane drag characteristics - engine performance characteristics - maximum, optimum, minimum altitudes - speeds and speed limits - speed and altitude capability with one engine inoperative engine performance characteristics Generally, in the cockpit preparation phase and before starting to program the FMGS, the pilots will check both databases. The performance database is checked by confirming the Engine and Aircraft type as well as the performance factor. The navigation database validity is checked by confirming the current day is within the validity interval. If any of these databases are wrong (wrong engine/aircraft or validity expired) only an authorised mechanic can change it to the correct one.

content.question: When performing the FMS pre-flight set-up, the pilot notices that the current navigation database is out of date. Which of the following is the action he/she should take before continuing the FMS initialisation? The pilot should…

options.A: Change the date via the on-board clock.
options.B: Download a new database via ACARS.
options.C: Select a new database from the EFB.
options.D: Select the valid database.

key_points: The navigation database needs to be updated after 28 days of use
If the database is not updated, it is not allowed to be used for navigational purposes
Before using the active database for navigation, the pilots have to verify that it has not already expire
learning.explanation: The navigation database needs to be updated after 28 days of use. If the database is not updated, it is not allowed to be used for navigational purposes. Before using the active database for navigation, the pilots have to verify that it has not already expire. The FMS can be pre-loaded with a second, "standby" database. When the active database reaches its date of expiry, the standby database becomes effective and can be used for navigation.

content.question: Which of the following statements regarding the "performance factor" is correct? It is a…

options.A: cost index used to show the efficiency of the aircraft as a percentage of the nominal performance.
options.B: positive or negative factor that is used to correct the predicted fuel flow.
options.C: positive or negative factor that is used to calculate the percentage error in fuel consumption due to differences between nominal and icing conditions.
options.D: positive factor that is used to show the percentage increase in fuel consumption when there is an abnormal increase in drag.

key_points: Performance factor is obtained from the aircraft performance monitoring program every airplane from an operator’s given fleet is subject to
This index can be found on the operational flight plan provided to the flight crew before each flight so that it is crosschecked and corrected if it differs from the FMS
In fact, this factor is very important because it is used during the flight planning stage of the flight and it is a reference for the FMGS to maximize fuel economy on each and every sector
learning.explanation: Performance factor is obtained from the aircraft performance monitoring program every airplane from an operator’s given fleet is subject to. This index can be found on the operational flight plan provided to the flight crew before each flight so that it is crosschecked and corrected if it differs from the FMS. In fact, this factor is very important because it is used during the flight planning stage of the flight and it is a reference for the FMGS to maximize fuel economy on each and every sector. The performance factor will ‘guide’ the FMS to provide the optimum speeds, profiles, cruise levels, for better fuel predictions and more accurate managed operation information. In order to increase the fuel savings, the performance factor will help to correct the predicted fuel flow when the actual aircraft drag, and engine performance differs from the nominal model due to the aircraft’s age. On the Airbus A320, you can find the performance factor on the ‘A/C STATUS’ page after selecting the DATA selector key on the MCDU. The performance factor is situated right next to the idle factor and can either be positive or negative.

metadata.topic: Flight Management System (FMS)/Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS)

content.question: Which system is required in order for the FMS to control vertical navigation?

options.A: Pitch Controller
options.B: Autothrottle
options.C: Electronic Flight Bag
options.D: Flight Director

key_points: It is true that there’re aircraft capable of controlling the vertical navigation without the autothrottle system
However, in this case the vertical navigation is not controlled by the FMS ONLY, but also by the pilot as he/she will act on the throttle levers
Therefore, in order to let the FMS to conducting all the vertical navigation, your aircraft definitely needs an autothrottle system
learning.explanation: It is true that there’re aircraft capable of controlling the vertical navigation without the autothrottle system. However, in this case the vertical navigation is not controlled by the FMS ONLY, but also by the pilot as he/she will act on the throttle levers. Therefore, in order to let the FMS to conducting all the vertical navigation, your aircraft definitely needs an autothrottle system. On a large commercial aircraft, the auto-throttle system usually has the following modes of operation: SPEED/MACH mode (holding of IAS/Mach number) and THRUST mode (N1 or EPR hold). In fact, the autopilot pitch channel and the auto-throttle system work together. The operating mode of one will determine the operating mode of the other. Find in this table, the summary of the autothrottle modes of operation and the respective flight phase: Flight phase Autothrottle mode Meaning Ground / TO roll N1 hold autothrottle commands full thrust for take-off. Climb IAS hold autothrottle commands full thrust for climb and the desired speed is maintained by the AP pitch channel. Climb with V/S IAS hold autothrottle continuously regulates the thrust output to maintain the required speed. Cruise / ALT hold IAS/MACH hold autothrottle continuously regulates the thrust output to maintain the required speed. Approach IAS hold autothrottle continuously regulates the thrust output to maintain the required speed.

metadata.topic: Flight Management System (FMS)/Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS)

content.question: In a dual FMS architecture, what happens if one of the FMS fails?

options.A: Pilots have to make an FMS reset as soon as possible.
options.B: If one FMS fails, the second will be lost as well.
options.C: The operative FMS will continue sending inputs to the failed FMS in order to recover it.
options.D: Redundancy is lost, the operative FMS will fully take over.

key_points: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions)
In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave
Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus
learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

content.question: After the pilot has set up the FMS and inserted an initial fuel quantity, the aircraft is still being refuelled. After refuelling, there's a big difference between the actual fuel and the fuel quantity inserted into the FMS. Which option is correct?

options.A: A significant difference between the measured and inserted values will trigger an error caption.
options.B: The calculations for the flight will be wrong and can only be corrected by re-initialising the FMS.
options.C: Since the fuel quantity is critical data, the FMS computer will freeze and stop to calculate VNAV and LNAV data and must be reset.
options.D: There is NO problem as the inserted quantity will be automatically updated to the actual value.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: We would like to inform you that the correct option for this question has recently been updated to "A significant difference between the measured and inserted values will trigger an error caption
" This update was made based on recent feedback
However, we would like to clarify that we do not entirely agree with this change
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: We would like to inform you that the correct option for this question has recently been updated to "A significant difference between the measured and inserted values will trigger an error caption." This update was made based on recent feedback. However, we would like to clarify that we do not entirely agree with this change. According to our perspective, we believe that option D, which states, "There is NO problem as the inserted quantity will be automatically updated to the actual value," should be considered the correct answer. If you encounter this question during your official exam, we kindly request you to inform us about it. MCDU INIT FUEL PRED PAGE The pilot uses this page to initialise the gross weight, center of gravity and block fuel, before starting the engines. The FMGC will stop using the pilot-entered block fuel and will compute its predictions based on the FOB indicated by the FQI computer after the first engine start. BLOCK: Crew may enter a block fuel for planning purposes. However, the FMS will take the fuel onboard from the fuel quantity indication system. After the aircraft is refuelled, the pilots should: - Check that the indicated Fuel On Board (FOB) corresponds to the Flight Plan - Check that if any imbalance is present, it is within the limits - compare the planned and actual uplift in mass (kgs or lbs). This will allow to identify any error or discrepancy that happened during the refuelling process. These discrepancies are generally limited by the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) and if out of limits a maintenance action is due.

content.question: All GPS signal inputs to the FMS are lost. What is one implication of this?

options.A: The system will be unable to navigate directly by using great circles.
options.B: The integrity monitoring (RAIM) for RNP approaches will be lost.
options.C: The IRS position will be slower to update.
options.D: The displayed position will be offset.

key_points: Most FMS use the GPS system as the main means to receive inertial position verification, that features its own fault detection option known as receiver autonomous integrity monitoring (RAIM)
RNP is a PBN system that includes onboard performance monitoring and alerting capability (for example, Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring (RAIM))
If RAIM is lost, which it is in this case, RNP approaches are compromised
learning.explanation: Most FMS use the GPS system as the main means to receive inertial position verification, that features its own fault detection option known as receiver autonomous integrity monitoring (RAIM). RNP is a PBN system that includes onboard performance monitoring and alerting capability (for example, Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring (RAIM)). If RAIM is lost, which it is in this case, RNP approaches are compromised. "The IRS position will be slower to update." Incorrect. IRS position is only updated when the aircraft is stationary on the ground.

content.question:
For most FMS the fuel prediction function, which computes the remaining fuel along the flight plan, takes into account the following situations:
1. the gross weight of the aircraft
2. the current wind computed or the resulting ground speed
3. the additional drag in case the landing gear remains extended
4. the additional drag resulting in a missing fuselage or wing element in compliance with the CDL (Configuration Deviation List)
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The FMS is an aid tool for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance
In order to provide the most correct fuel predictions, the FMS needs to know the weight of the aircraft, its cruising level, and the current wind
The FMS has also the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration
learning.explanation: The FMS is an aid tool for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance. In order to provide the most correct fuel predictions, the FMS needs to know the weight of the aircraft, its cruising level, and the current wind. The FMS has also the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration. This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions.

content.question: During the cockpit preparation phase, the flight crew notices that the Performance Database is incorrect on the FMS, being for a different aircraft and engine type. What must they do in this case?

options.A: Nothing, this is not an issue.
options.B: Proceed with the flight but notify the maintenance crew.
options.C: Manually select the correct database.
options.D: The mechanics must change the database.

key_points: The information stored in the FMC is called its database
The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation
The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model
learning.explanation: The information stored in the FMC is called its database. The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation. The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model. The data stored in the database includes aircraft drag and engine characteristics, maximum and minimum speeds. Maintenance can refine the database for each aircraft by entering factors for drag and fuel flow Generally, in the cockpit preparation phase and before starting to program the FMGS, the pilots will check both databases. The performance database is checked by confirming the Engine and Aircraft type as well as the performance factor. The navigation database validity is checked by confirming the current day is within the validity interval. If any of these databases are wrong (wrong engine/aircraft or validity expired) an authorised mechanic has to change it to the correct one.

content.question: In the navigation database, waypoint 'EASAT' is defined by the intersection of 'HSBJ' VOR radial 320 and radial 263 from 'HSBM' VOR. This waypoint is a...

options.A: place/distance (PD) waypoint.
options.B: place/bearing/distance (PBD) waypoint.
options.C: place/bearing - place/bearing (PBX) waypoint.
options.D: latitude/longitude coordinates waypoint.

key_points: The pilot can identify a waypoint by: ‐ Its identifier (if it is in the navigation database)
‐ A Latitude/Longitude (LL)
‐ A Place/Bearing/Distance (PBD)
learning.explanation: The pilot can identify a waypoint by: ‐ Its identifier (if it is in the navigation database). ‐ A Latitude/Longitude (LL). ‐ A Place/Bearing/Distance (PBD). The waypoint is defined by its bearing and distance from a place. ‐ A Place-Bearing/Place-Bearing (PBX). The waypoint is defined by the interception of 2 radials from 2 places. ‐ A Place/Distance (PD). The waypoint is defined by a distance from a place, along the F-PLN. To insert a PBX, WRITE the waypoint identifier Place-Bearing/Place-Bearing into the scratchpad. (Example: Place: LMG, Bearing: 330°). PRESS the appropriate key to enter the waypoint into the flight plan. When the Flight Management Guidance System receives a waypoint that is not in the database, it identifies it as LLxx or PBD xx or PBX xx or PD xx (xx is a two-digit number between 01 and 20) and stores it in the stored waypoints file of the database.

content.question: What information must the pilots input/check with regards to the FMS before take-off?

options.A: Input data from the load sheet.
options.B: Ensure the performance database is up to date.
options.C: Input the alternate airport routing.
options.D: Destination weather input.

key_points: Note: This question is based on unverified feedback
Please put any exam feedback in the comments, or email it to info@atplquestions
com, thank you
learning.explanation: Note: This question is based on unverified feedback. Please put any exam feedback in the comments, or email it to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. The FMS (Flight Management System) is the main computer that the pilots use to interface with the aircraft's more complex systems. Before a flight, the pilots will spend many minutes checking through the various pages in the FMS, making sure the data is correct, and inputting things such as the route, weights, clearances, temperatures, etc. The pilots can input many of these items from the OFP (Operational Flight Plan) which is part of the briefing pack the pilots have before the flight. Some of this data, however, such as updated weights and centre of gravity locations, arrive on the load sheet handed to the PIC by the dispatcher. The values on the load sheet then have to be checked/inputted into the FMS to make sure that the weights and CofG limits are correct for the flight. There are also databases in the FMS, and these are comprised of the navigation database and the performance database. These both need to be checked. The navigation database must be checked for time validity and the performance database must be checked to see if it contains the correct data, for example if it pertains to the correct aircraft variant with the correct engines. The alternate airport routing would not normally be entered into the FMS, unless it was expected to be used soon after take-off, which of course would be a scenario where taking off is not advisable in the first place. We do not input destination weather on most systems (and certainly not before take off).

content.question: An aeroplane departs for a 12 hour long flight at 20:00 UTC on the 8th of the Month. During the preparation, the flight crew notices that their navigation database is only valid until the 8th of the month. What should they do?

options.A: The should manually change to the new database at 00:00 UTC on the 9th, in flight.
options.B: They do not have to do anything, it is activated automatically.
options.C: Load the new database prior to departure.
options.D: Use current data.

key_points: Navigation databases run in 28 day cycles, on the same dates as the AIRAC cycles, and it is a legal requirement for flying IFR to use the current navigation database (some procedures are allowed to be performed with an out-of-date database as long as differences are checked and it is less than 1 cycle out of date, but more on this in the annex above)

Almost all systems have an active and a standby database, where the standby database can be uploaded onto the avionics before change-over, and the data will change to the newer database automatically on the next startup of the avionics after the change-over, or updated manually by the pilots from standby to active
This makes it easier for engineers to be able to update the aircraft standby databases in the few days leading up to the change-over
learning.explanation: Navigation databases run in 28 day cycles, on the same dates as the AIRAC cycles, and it is a legal requirement for flying IFR to use the current navigation database (some procedures are allowed to be performed with an out-of-date database as long as differences are checked and it is less than 1 cycle out of date, but more on this in the annex above). Almost all systems have an active and a standby database, where the standby database can be uploaded onto the avionics before change-over, and the data will change to the newer database automatically on the next startup of the avionics after the change-over, or updated manually by the pilots from standby to active. This makes it easier for engineers to be able to update the aircraft standby databases in the few days leading up to the change-over. In the rare case that an aircraft is flying through the change-over, the pilots should NOT change the database in the air, as database corruption could make their avionics unusable if it goes wrong, so should remain on the old database, and check their routings, SIDs, STARs, and all waypoints with charts and can check the update notes (and NOTAMs) to see what has changed also. As long as their routes are still correct, and some other items mentioned in the annex above, the flight is still allowed. Note: This question has been moved from incorrectly placed feedback in AGK. The correct answer is also missing quite a bit of detail, which does make it slightly ambiguous, so if anyone has further exam feedback about this, please put it in the comments or email it to info@atplquestions.com.

learning.explanation: The navigation database of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav database is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports Navaids Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.

content.question: Under normal conditions, in a dual FMS architecture, the master FMC sends its commands to the: (NB: FMC = Flight Management Computer)

options.A: the first officer instruments.
options.B: the captain instruments.
options.C: autopilot, flight director, and autothrottle/collective.
options.D: the captain autopilot.

key_points: Some of the most sophisticated aircraft have complete dual FMS, two CDUs, and dula AFCS
A dual FMS system can be used in several ways: Dual mode (Master/Slave) – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions)
In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave
learning.explanation: Some of the most sophisticated aircraft have complete dual FMS, two CDUs, and dula AFCS. A dual FMS system can be used in several ways: Dual mode (Master/Slave) – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle/collective. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals. Back-up - When the FMC has failed in certain areas, but still retains a limited FMS function.

content.question: What is true about the FMC databases…

options.A: the data includes SIDs, STARS and runway approaches.
options.B: the data can not be customized for the specific airline operations.
options.C: the performance database contains aeronautical information for the planned area of operations of the aircraft.
options.D: the navigation database contains the company’s cost index strategy.

key_points: “The data includes SIDs, STARS and runway approaches
” – CORRECT
The SIDs, STARs, and runway approaches are all included in the navigation database of the FMC
learning.explanation: “The data includes SIDs, STARS and runway approaches.” – CORRECT. The SIDs, STARs, and runway approaches are all included in the navigation database of the FMC. It can also include airports, navaids, airways, waypoints, magnetic variations, company routes, and holding patterns. “The data can not be customized for the specific airline operations” – INCORRECT. All the data can be customized for each operator so that it corresponds to their fleet, flown routes, and preferences. “The performance database contains aeronautical information for the planned area of operations of the aircraft.” – INCORRECT. The “planned area of operations” are most probably the different airports and runways stored in the database. These are stored in the navigation database. “The navigation database contains the company’s cost index strategy.” – INCORRECT. Cost index strategy is stored in the performance database of the FMS.

key_points: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database

This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database. The Performance Database contains an average model of the aeroplane and its engines. This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands. Additionally, the relevant data can be displayed and this reduces the need for the flight crew to refer to a performance manual during flight. The data stored includes: - aeroplane drag characteristics aeroplane drag characteristics - engine performance characteristics - maximum, optimum, minimum altitudes - speeds and speed limits - speed and altitude capability with one engine inoperative engine performance characteristics The maintenance group for individual aeroplanes can refine this data, by entering correction factors for drag and fuel flow, which are retained in the NV RAM for continued use.

content.question:
The role of the FMS is to aid the flight crew with:
1 – immediate actions in case of emergency procedure
2 – navigation
3 – in-flight performance optimisation
4 – electronic check-lists.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

key_points: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory

The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing the following major functions: Aid for fuel management - improve fuel efficiency and performance optimization: The FMS has the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration
This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions
learning.explanation: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory. The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing the following major functions: Aid for fuel management - improve fuel efficiency and performance optimization: The FMS has the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration. This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions. Aid with navigation - lateral and vertical flight plan management: The FMS calculates the aircraft trajectory so that it respects any inserted constraints (altitude, speed, distance, etc. Aircraft position computation: The FMS computed position along the flight plan is derived from the data provided by the IRS, DME, VOR, and GPS. A monitoring section is provided in the MCDU where you can actually check the accuracy and integrity of the GPS signal and select the desired position computation method. Autotuning – automatic tuning of the radio navigation frequencies. The autotuning function automatically tunes the radio navigation facilities based on the available signals in terms of geometry and strength. The workload is greatly reduced because the flight crew only need to cross-check with their charts that the correct frequencies are automatically inserted.

Message will remain displayed until the condition has been resolved

learning.explanation: ALERTING MESSAGE: FMC DISAGREE During approach or on the ground, monitored parameters required for dual FMC operation are in disagreement (Dual FMC as installed). Message will remain displayed until the condition has been resolved. The FMC does not check for mach and indicated airspeed miscompares on the ground. Corrective action: Monitor FMCs closely. Both FMCs remain online. Limit approaches to single FMC only. If desired, revert to single FMC operation.

content.question: What are the consequences if the GPS position inputs to the FMS are reduced?

options.A: The FMS will become inoperative but the RNAV approaches will still be available.
options.B: The FMS will become inoperative.
options.C: The aircraft might experience position computation problems and potentially a map shift on the ND.
options.D: Position computation is less accurate and RNAV approaches are not available anymore.

key_points: The Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS) performs navigation functions and lateral and vertical flight planning functions
It also computes performance parameters and guides the aircraft along a preplanned route

The Flight Management (FM) part controls the following functions: - Navigation - Management of flight planning - Prediction and optimisation of performance - Management of navigation radios - Management of displays The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position
learning.explanation: The Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS) performs navigation functions and lateral and vertical flight planning functions. It also computes performance parameters and guides the aircraft along a preplanned route. The Flight Management (FM) part controls the following functions: - Navigation - Management of flight planning - Prediction and optimisation of performance - Management of navigation radios - Management of displays The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position. Each IRS computes a mixed IRS/GPS position called the GPIRS position. For this, each IRS can independently select their GPS source in order to maximize the availability of GPS data. If the GPIRS data does not comply with an integrity criterion that is based on a Horizontal Integrity Limit (HIL) and on the automatic detection of failed satellites, the FMS rejects the GPS mode and uses the radio position update. The flight crew can deselect/select the GPS position on the SELECTED NAVAIDS page, if necessary. Without GPS PRIMARY (GPS deselected or inoperative) the navigation accuracy is lower and is a function of ground radio navaid infrastructure or elapsed time since the last radio update. RNAV(GNSS) approaches may be performed, provided GPS PRIMARY is available and with AP or FD engaged. The flight crew may check the position computation using the POSITION MONITOR page.
